IgM DENV positive samples tested by MAC-ELISA, 39 cross-reacted and presented false positive results for ZIKV and 25 were inconclusive or undetermined. the novel neutralization test presented 50.53% less cross reactivity than MAC-ELISA, and the rate of correct identification of ZIKV negative serum increased from 32.63% to 83.16%. a definitive ZIKV diagnosis is achieved by detecting viral RNA in patient serum, or other samples like urine, semen and placenta. a serologic test must be employed for individuals beyond this viremia window. the most common method is the detection of reactive IgM antibodies. novel ELISA based on recombinant ZIKV non-structural protein 1 (NS1) was able to eliminate cross-reactions with antibodies to DENV and other flaviviruses. a CDC diagnostic guideline recommends that presumptive positive or equivocal MAC-ELISA result for ZIKV needs to be verified with a confirmatory PRNT. the assay maintained relative specificity of traditional PRNT. it was further evaluated with 258 clinical serum specimens. a neutralization assay in which the endpoint is measured by real-time PCR was proposed. people exposed to secondary DENV infections develop broadly neutralizing antibodies that neutralize different serotypes other than the one responsible for current infection [31]. sera from patients with secondary DENV infection exhibit potent cross-reactivity against ZIKV [11], as it was demonstrated in the DENV fluorescent neutralization test. higher cut off values may reduce assay sensibility, i.e., some samples of ZIKV early infections can become inconclusive. the developed fluorescent neutralization test offers significant advantages over classical PRNT. it is faster, prompt to high throughput adaptation, has automated reading of results.
